facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 132 of 1954 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 132 of 1954. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1953,

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1953, of the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1953, of the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi in Civil Writ Application No. 314 of 1952.

facts.text: High Court allowed Civil Writ Application No. 314 of 1952 filed by Jagan Nath.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Jagan Nath filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Punjab High Court which was allowed.

facts.text: High Court ordered Union of India and Sohan Lal to restore possession of house No. 35 in West Patel Nagar, Delhi to Jagan Nath.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court ordered the respondent The Union of India and the appellant Sohan Lal to forthwith restore possession of house No. 35 situated in West Patel Nagar, Delhi to Jagan Nath.

facts.text: Jagan Nath is a displaced person and refugee from Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order of the High Court the appellant applied for and obtained special leave to appeal to this Court. Jagan Nath is a displaced person and a refugee from Pakistan.

facts.text: Government of India devised schemes for rehabilitation of refugees including sale of houses constructed in West Patel Nagar.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India had devised various schemes for the rehabilitation of refugees. One of these was a scheme for sale of certain houses constructed by the Government of India for refugees in West Patel Nagar.

facts.text: Scheme intended to entertain applications from displaced persons already allotted agricultural land in East Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: It was intended -under the scheme to entertain applications from displaced persons who had already been allotted agricultural land in East Punjab. A limited number of houses known as box-type tenements were constructed.

facts.text: Eligibility for allotment: displaced persons registered before August 15, 1948, and gainfully employed.

anchor.surface_text: According to -he procedure prescribed in order to give effect to the scheme, only those displaced persons, who were registered before the 15th of August, 1948, and were gain- fully employed, were eligible for allotment of a house.

facts.text: Jagan Nath registered as a refugee on December 31, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath had got himself registered as a refugee on December 31, 1947.

facts.text: Jagan Nath made application in prescribed form for house in West Patel Nagar.

anchor.surface_text: He had made his application in the prescribed form. He had deposited the sum of Rs. 5,600 as the sale price after his prima facie eligibility had been accepted.

facts.text: Jagan Nath deposited Rs. 5,600 as sale price after prima facie eligibility accepted.

anchor.surface_text: He had deposited the sum of Rs. 5,600 as the sale price after his prima facie eligibility had been accepted. He had also deposited the ground rent for the plot on which the house had been built,

facts.text: Jagan Nath deposited ground rent for the plot.

anchor.surface_text: He had also deposited the ground rent for the plot on which the house had been built, having been informed previously that it had been decided to allot him a two-roomed enclosed verandah box-type house in West Patel Nagar.

facts.text: Jagan Nath informed that allotment by drawing lots on February 15, 1952 at 3 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: He was informed that the allotment of a particular house would be decided by drawing lots at site on February 15, 1952, at 3 p.m.

facts.text: House No. 35 fell to Jagan Nath's lot as result of drawing lots.

anchor.surface_text: As the result of the drawing of lots, house No. 35, the property in dispute in this appeal, fell to his lot.

facts.text: On May 10, 1952, Accommodation Officer removed Jagan Nath's family and belongings to house No. 35 in his absence.

anchor.surface_text: According to Jagan Nath, on May 10, 1952, the Accommodation Officer in his absence removed the members of his family along with his entire belongings to the house in dispute in a truck and he and his family thus entered into possession of the house in dispute.

facts.text: Jagan Nath evicted from house on September 27, 1952 by warrant dated September 11, 1952 under s. 25 of Ordinance III of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath, however, was evicted from the house in dispute on September 27, 1952, by virtue of a warrant of eviction dated September 11, 1952, purporting to have been issued under s. 25 of Ordinance III of 1952.

facts.text: Possession of house given to Sohan Lal on October 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: After his eviction,possession of the house in dispute was given to the appellant on October 3, 1952.

facts.text: Sohan Lal is a displaced person.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, who is also a displaced person, had applied on February 27, 1952, for allotment of a house in West Patel Nagar.

facts.text: Sohan Lal applied for allotment on February 27, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, who is also a displaced person, had applied on February 27, 1952, for allotment of a house in West Patel Nagar.

facts.text: Sohan Lal deposited Rs. 5,600 as sale price.

anchor.surface_text: He had made the deposit of Rs. 5,600 as sale price and had apparently complied with all the necessary conditions for allotment of a house to him

facts.text: House No. 35 allotted to Sohan Lal on July 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and the house in dispute was allotted to him on July 31, 1952. The appellant has been in possession of the disputed house since October 3, 1952.

facts.text: Sohan Lal in possession since October 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has been in possession of the disputed house since October 3, 1952.

facts.text: Jagan Nath was allotted agricultural land in District of Hissar.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Union of India is that under the scheme Jagan Nath was not eligible for allotment of a house in West Patel Nagar, as it was subsequently discovered that he had been allotted, previous to his application, agricultural land in the District of Hissar.

facts.text: No letter of allotment issued to Jagan Nath.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath had entered into a transaction with the Union of India upto a certain stage with respect to the property in dispute, but no letter of allotment had been issued him.

facts.text: Union of India informed Jagan Nath that property could not be allotted as he was allotted land in East Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, he had been informed, when certain facts became known, that the property in question could not be allotted to him as he was a displaced person who had been allotted land in East Punjab.

facts.text: Letter of allotment issued to Sohan Lal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had complied with all the conditions imposed by the Union of India and a letter of allotment was actually issued to him and he entered into possession

facts.text: Eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of s. 3 of Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act. His eviction, therefore, was illegal.

facts.text: No evidence of collusion between appellant and Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence and no finding of the High Court that the appellant was in collusion with the Union of India or that he had knowledge that the eviction of Jagan Nath was illegal.

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on March 7, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. March 7. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM J.--The respondent Jagan Nath filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in allowing the application of Jagan Nath filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution and making the order it did. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

issues.text: Whether, having regard to the serious disputes on questions of fact and title, the High Court erred in exercising jurisdiction under Art. 226 of the Constitution to declare title and order restoration of possession

anchor.surface_text: The appellants main contention has been that, having regard to the circumstances of the case, the High Court erred in making the order it did which presumably purported to be in the nature of a writ of mandamus. There was a serious dispute on questions of fact between the parties and also whether Jagan Nath had acquired in law any title to the property in dispute. Proceedings by way of a writ were not appropriate in a case where the decision of the Court would amount to a decree declaring Jagan Naths title and ordering restoration of possession. The proper remedy open to Jagan Nath was to get his title declared in the ordinary way in a Civil Court.

issues.text: Whether a writ of mandamus or order in the nature of mandamus can be made against the appellant, a private individual in possession without evidence of collusion with the Union of India

anchor.surface_text: The property in dispute, however, is in possession of the appellant. There is no evidence and no finding of the High Court that the appellant was in collusion with the Union of India or that he had knowledge that the eviction of Jagan Nath was illegal. Normally, a writ of mandamus does not issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus is not made against a private individual.

issues.text: Whether the eviction of Jagan Nath was illegal for contravention of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950 requiring prior notice

anchor.surface_text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act. His eviction, therefore, was illegal. He was entitled to be evicted in due course of law and a writ of mandamus could issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus could be made against the Union of India to restore possession of the property to Jagan Nath from which he had been evicted if the property was still in the possession of the Union of India.

issues.text: What rights, if any, were acquired by Jagan Nath in the property as against the Union of India up to the stage when he was informed that it would not be allotted to him

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath had entered into a transaction with the Union of India upto a certain stage with respect to the property in dispute, but no letter of allotment had been issued him. Indeed, he had been informed, when certain facts became known, that the property in question could not be allotted to him as he was a displaced person who had been allotted land in East Punjab. As between Jagan Nath and the Union of India it will be necessary to decide what rights were acquired by the former in the property upto the stage when the latter informed Jagan Nath that the property would not be allotted to him.

issues.text: Whether Jagan Nath was allowed to enter into possession because the property was allotted to him or under a misapprehension as the Union of India was misled by the contents of his application

anchor.surface_text: Another question for decision will be whether Jagan Nath was allowed to enter into possession of the property because it was allotted to him or under a misapprehension as the Union of India was misled by the contents of his application. The case of the Union of India is that under the scheme Jagan Nath was not eligible for allotment of a house in West Patel Nagar, as it was subsequently discovered that he had been allotted, previous to his application, agricultural land in the District of Hissar.

issues.text: Did the appellant acquire a legal right to hold the property as against Jagan Nath

anchor.surface_text: Being satisfied that Jagan Nath was not eligible for allotment, the Union of India refused to allot to him the tenement No. 35, West Patel Nagar and allotment of that house was made to the appellant who was found to be eligible in every way. The appellant was accordingly given possession of the property after Jagan Naths eviction. The appellant had complied with all the conditions imposed by the Union of India and a letter of allotment was actually issued to him and he entered into possession of the property in dispute under the authority of the Union of India. Did the appellant thereby acquire a legal right to hold the property as against Jagan Nath?

arguments.claim: High Court erred in allowing Art. 226 petition and ordering restoration; appeal allowed, order set aside

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in allowing the application of Jagan Nath filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution and making the order it did. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

holdings.text: Proceedings under Article 226 of the Constitution are not appropriate for enquiring into merits of rival title claims involving disputed questions of fact and law; such matters are for civil courts.

anchor.surface_text: We do not propose to enquire into the merits of the rival claims of title to the property in dispute set up by the appellant and Jagan Nath. If we were to do so, we would be entering into a field of investigation which is more

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disputed facts and title require investigation by civil court; writ jurisdiction not for passing decrees declaring title and possession.

holdings.text: All questions regarding rights acquired by Jagan Nath, eligibility under scheme, basis of possession entry, and appellant's legal right to property should be decided in civil suit, not under Article 226.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Multiple disputed factual and legal issues necessitate full trial in civil court rather than summary writ proceedings.

holdings.text: Eviction of Jagan Nath contravened s. 3 of Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950, rendering it illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act. His eviction, therefore, was illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory notice under s.3 not served before eviction warrant executed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illegal eviction permits mandamus against public authority responsible if they retain possession.

holdings.text: Principle from election cases applies by analogy: mandamus not against de facto possessor without proving colourable transaction; quo warranto or equivalent needed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No distinction in principle between de facto office holder and bona fide property possessor; title challenged via appropriate proceedings.

holdings.text: High Court erred in allowing writ petition under Article 226 and ordering restoration of possession; appeal allowed and High Court order set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in allowing the application of Jagan Nath filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution and making the order it did. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdictional error in entertaining writ for title dispute without resolving factual issues.

precedents.citation: Khushal Singh v. Shri Rameshwar Dayal, Deputy Commissioner, Delhi 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed upon certain decisions of the High Courts of Punjab in Khushal Singh v. Shri Rameshwar Dayal, Deputy Commissioner, Delhi 1 , Hyderabad in G. Kistareddy v. Commr. of City Police, Hyderabad 2  and Pepsu in Mohinder Singh v. State of Pepsu 1 , as well as certain observations in the judgment of this Court in the case of Wazir Chand v. The state of Himachal Pradesh 4  in support of the proposition that, as Jagan Nath was in possession and he had been illegally evicted, he was entitled to have property, from which he had been illegally evicted, restored to him.

anchor.surface_text: In R. v. Chester Corporation 1 it was held that it is an inflexible rule of law that where a person has been de facto elected to a corporate office, and has accepted and acted in the office, the validity of the election and the title to the office can only be tried by proceeding on a quo warranto information. A mandamus will not lie unless the election can be shown to be merely colourable.

precedents.cited_proposition: mandamus will not lie against de facto possessor of office unless colourable; quo warranto needed
precedents.cited_holding: it is an inflexible rule of law that where a person has been de facto elected to a corporate office, and has accepted and acted in the office, the validity of the election and the title to the office can only be tried by proceeding on a quo warranto information. A mandamus will not lie unless the election can be shown to be merely colourable.
